channel.title: Quadratic equations and factoring
channel.description: Okay I am in geometry now and I haven't done these in a while. Can someone tell me how to solve it??? Quadratic equations and factoring ><<

item.title: Quadratic equations and factoring
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Of course it isn’t, which is why I didn’t solve it as one. You only solved for the x-intercept in one of the linear equations though. Typically when you are told to solve a pair (or set) of linear equations, it is implied that you are looking for the point of intersection, which is what I solved for. You answer could have very well been what he was looking for, but as he didn’t specify one way or the other, I solved the pair of equations together.

Read full topic

item.title: Quadratic equations and factoring
item.dc:creator: @Chimaera_God Chimaera God
item.description:
@Chimaera_God wrote:

BobDole, that last equation isn’t quadratic, it’s a linear eqaution. An equation can only be a Quadratic equation when it is in the form of ax^2+bx+c, or if the equation has a power of two.

As for the equation:

3x + 4y = 12 <-------Seeing that the equation is true, assume that both varibles are equal to zero.
3(0) + 4y = 12 <-------Now substitute for y
4y = 12 <-------Divide 12 by 4
y = 3 <------ Now just do all of this to find x. You get x = 4.

Read full topic

item.title: Quadratic equations and factoring
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

I assume both of the first two are set equal to 0.

x^2 + 5x + 6 = 0
(x + 3)(x + 2) = 0
x = {-2, -3}

Since there is no coefficient for x^2, you need to find two numbers such that their sum is 5 and their
product is 6. Not too complicated, right?

x^2 + 5x + 1 = 0

This one cannot be factored easily (as the roots are obviously irrational), so you must use the quadratic equation.

x = [-b ± √(b^2 - 4ac)] / 2a
x = [-5 ± √(5^2 - 4(1)(1))] / 2(1)
x = [-5 ± √(25 - 4)] / 2
x = [-5 ± √21] / 2

This can’t really be simplified much further, so:

x = {(-5 + √21) / 2, (-5 - √21) / 2}

You can approximate the values if you’d like.

This doesn’t look like a quadratic to me…if both expressions are assumed to be true, then you can solve simultaneously. For this case, substitution would be easiest.

3x + 4y = 12
3x + 4(x + 1) = 12
3x + 4x + 4 = 12
7x = 8
x = 8/7

y = x + 1
y = 8/7 + 1
y = 15/7

Read full topic

item.title: Quadratic equations and factoring
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

For factoring quadratic equations (in the form ax^2 + bx + c = 0), you need to be able to deduce two values, p and q, such that pq = c and a[sub]1[/sub]q + a[sub]2[/sub]p = b. When a = 1, its easier - p + q = b. But when a is not 1, it may take a bit more work. If you have a specific question, we can show you how to factor it.

For the quadratic equation, following the same coefficient values in the quadratic form I have above:

x = [-b ± √(b^2 - 4ac)] / 2a

This will allow you to solve for the roots of the quadratic equation. Again, if you need specific help with a problem, we can use one or both of the above methods to solve it.

Read full topic
